titleStmt.title: Proposed Site Index Entries from Our Village: Sketches of Rural Character and Scenery

sponsor.orgName: Mary Russell Mitford Society: Digital Mitford Project

editionStmt.edition: This file is born digital in TEI P5, date: 2023-06-25-04:00.

publicationStmt.p: Internal file for the Digital Mitford project team.

sourceDesc.p: The source document on which this is based is a file of proposed new site index entries. The number of proposed site index entries in the source file is 587.

org.note: Considered the first professional police force in London, and a precursor to the Metropolitan Police, the Bow Street Runners were founded by Henry Fielding in 1749. The organization was later expanded by his brother, John. The goal of the group was to centralize informal methods of thief-taking under the authority of a magistrate and to cut rising crime rates. The group was incorporated into the Metropolitan Police Force in 1839.
The principal land warfare force of the United Kingdom.

Prominent, ancient English family whose chief estate, Beaurepaire House, was located near Bramley. The family traces its lineage back to the age of William the Conqueror, and was in possession of many acres of land and cottages in the environs of Bramley since the the sixteenth century, including Beaurepaire House and Wokefield Park.
The University in Cambridge. The school was established in 1209.
A cricket venue in St. John's Wood founded by Thomas Lord. It houses the Marylebone Cricket Club.
Founded sometime around 1096, the university located in Oxford is considered the oldest in the English-speaking world.

person.note: English cleric who wrote popular works on natural history, travel, and music. His natural history works went into multiple editions until long after his death, including Animal Biography, which was in its sixth edition in 1824.
Member of the Brocas family, owner of Beaurepaire House and Wokefield Park. His death is memorialized by the Brocas monument.

Harriot Hunter Brocas was the daughter of a Swallowfield merchant who worked for the Levant Company. She married Bernard Brocas in 1769, and renovated Wokefield Park after her husband purchased it. Upon her death, a charity was established to house elderly widows in Wokefield.

The second son of Charles III, Charles assumed the throne of Spain instead of his older brother, who was passed over due to a learning disability and epilepsy. He left most of the management of the state to his wife, Maria Luisa, and the Prime Minister, but unstable relations with revolutionary France led to new alignments within his government that made his authority tenuous. Officially neutral toward France during the republican years, Spain was eventually invaded by Bonarparte along with Portugal, and Charles was forced to abdicate, as was his son, Ferdinand, his successor. When Spain was liberated from French rule after the Peninsular War, Charles spent the rest of his life in exile, finally settling in Rome.

Major figure in the English abolitionist movement. He was the son of a minister, and though he was educated for the church, he never formally took orders. Throughout his life, Clarkson agitated for the abolition of slavery both through the political process and as a persuasive abolitionist writer. He also founded several anti-slavery organizations. His chief practice was to travel throughout the country, gathering signatures of support for the cause, interviewing witnesses to slave trade practices, assembling evidence of its atrocities, and networking with various anti-slavery societies. Clarkson was instrumental in gathering support for the Abolition Bill of 1807, and the final Abolition Bill of 1833. It is estimated that he traveled some 35,000 miles in these endeavors.

Cowley was one of the leading poets and philosophical writers of his day, although not as well-known today as some of his contemporaries. He won fame at the age of fifteen for an elegy on the death of Lord Carlton. While a student at Cambridge, he composed one of his most famous works, the Davideis, an epic on the struggles of King David. During the Civil War, Cowley sided with the Royalists, and so had to endure a twelve-year exile in Paris after the loss of that side. In 1647, Cowley published The Chronicle, a satirical work in which he lists multiple women with whom he has had love affairs. In addition to poetry, Cowley also wrote a book on experimental farming.

English poet known for depicting rural life in realistic detail. His most famous works include The Village, The Parish Register, and The Borough. George Crabbe came from modest origins, initially training as a surgeon, but harboring literary ambitions. He earned the patronage and friendship of Edmund Burke, who introduced him into literary and political circles that included Charles James Fox and Samuel Johnson, and also helped procure him a living as a rector. His work was greatly influential on the romantic poets, who admired his representation of rural lives and spaces, although he was also sometimes derided for a lack of the poetical, including by Mitford.

person.persName: Guy Fawkes Fawkes Vaux Guy Guido Guydo
person.note: One of the chief conspirators who was hanged, drawn, and quartered for his role in the Gunpowder Plot. Born into a prominent protestant family, Fawkes converted to Catholicism while still a teenager. When he reached his maturity, he served as a mercenary in the Spanish army. Fearing the curtailing of Catholic rights because of King James I's support for the penal laws, he joined a group who planned to blow up Parliament while the king was inside the House of Lords. The date chosen for the action was November 5, 1605, but the plot was uncovered when some of the conspirators sought to warn Catholic Parliamentarians to avoid the site. The date of the foiled plot is traditionally celebrated in England as Guy Fawkes Day with bonfires, firecrackers, and fireworks.

After failing at law and squandering his fortune, Samuel Foote became an actor on the Dublin and London stages. He was noted for his skills in mimicry, which he used to mock fellow actors and other celebrities. He acted at Drury Lane (where he was joint-manager) and Covent Garden. He succeeded in gaining a lease on the Haymarket Theater, where he performed his own works of mimicry, which he styled teas to avoid licensing laws. The bulk of his theatrical works are satirical plays, often provoking to his contemporaries, particularly Henry Fielding. Nevertheless, he earned the admiration of Johnson, and the cautious friendship of David Garrick.

person.birth: February 6, 1778 Zakynthos, Greece (formerly Republic of Venice)
person.note: Born of a Venetian father and a Greek mother, Foscolo spent most of his early years in Venice when it was a Republic. His first work, a tragedy, enjoyed a modest success. He was an ardent admirer of Napoleon, and believed that Venice would become a true republic upon a French invasion. When Napoleon later ceded the city to Austria, Foscolo published an epistolary novel denouncing the move, The Last Letters of Jacopo Ortis. However, still fostering hope for a true Italian republic, Foscolo later joined the Italian division of the French army. In 1807, he wrote Dei Sepolcri , a long poem protesting Napoleon's ban on tomb inscriptions. He translated a number of English works. In 1816, he fled to England, where he contributed essays on Dante, Petrarch, and other Italian poets for the Quarterly Review and the Edinburgh Review. He became something of a celebrity, writing and teaching at a girls' school, until he was confined to debtors' prison. Nearly fifty years after his death, his remains were repatriated to Florence.

persName.roleName: Chancellor of the Exchequer for the Duchy of Saxe-Weimar
Superintendant of the Ducal Libary and Chief Advisor of Saxe-Weimar
Commissioner of the War, Mines, and Highways Commission

person.note: Renowned and influential author of novels, poems, plays, natural history, and criticism who popularized the Sturm und Drang movement associated with German Romanticism. Goethe began a career in law, but made his name with his first novel, The Sorrows of Young Werther, an epistolary text in which a young man commits suicide due to an unrequited love. On the strength of that success, Goethe was bestowed a nobility by the young Duke of Saxe-Weimar, and appointed to administrative government posts. He was also given the management of the Weimar Theater. During this period, he composed the first part of what is considered his magnum opus, the play Faust. Though he did not complete the work until shortly before his death, he published the first part in 1790, then revised versions in 1808 and 1828. Many composers adapted the play for opera, symphony, and oratorios, including Hector Berlioz, Frantz Liszt, and Richard Wagner. Another influential work was the novel Wilhelm Meister's Apprenticeship, which was also widely praised and adapted for music, theater, and the visual arts. Goethe's death was considered the end of a Romantic epoch on the same scale as Lord Byron's.

Matthew Green worked as a clerk in the Custom's House, and was the author several volumes of light verse, some of which was well regarded in its day. His poem The Spleen was published in 1737, and another poem written in honor of Queen Anne's Grotto at Richmond, entitled The Grotto was published in 1737. An edition of Green's works was reissued in 1796 with an introduction by John Aikin.

Joseph Grimaldi was one of the most famous clowns and comic actors of his day, acting in pantomimes from an early age. Born into a theatrical family, he was brought to the stage by his father, and had a long career at Sadler Wells, Drury Lane, and Covent Garden theaters, working with Charles Kemble and other important figures. He was most known for acting in pantomimes, and retired from the stage in 1823.

Known as the Cottage Countess,Sarah Hoggins was a farmer's daughter who married Henry Cecil. He was, unbeknownst to her, the heir to the Earldom of Exeter, and already married. The couple's portrait was painted by Thomas Lawrence, and the story of their courtship became fodder for many nineteenth-century writers and artists, including Tennyson and John Everett Millais. Mitford is likely drawing on an account of this story by William Hazlitt in Pictures at Burleigh House, published in the New Monthly Magazine in 1822. Their son, who inherited the father's title, later became a patron of the poet John Clare, something Mitford mentions in her chapter on Clare in Recollections of a Literary Life.

person.persName: Anne Hyde, Duchess of York and Albany Hyde Stuart Anne Duchess of York and Albany
person.note: Anne Hyde was the wife of King James II, and sister of Henry Hyde. Like her brother, she spent her early life in Belgium and the Netherlands. She met the future king while still in exile, and they married in 1660. Anne eventually converted to Catholicism along with her husband, though they pledged to raise their children in the Protestant faith. The couple had eight children, only two of whom lived to adulthood. Although Anne died before her husband became king, her two surviving children became monarchs, Mary II and Anne.

person.persName: Henry Hyde, Second Earl of Clarendon Hyde Henry
person.note: Henry Hyde, the second earl of Clarendon, spent much of his childhood in Belgium and the Netherlands because of his father's exile. When he returned to England in 1660, he secured a place as Member of Parliament for Wiltshire, then as Private Secretary to Queen Catherine, and her Lord Chamberlain. However, the latter position led to a protracted legal battle between Hyde and his employer. Thanks to his friendship with the Duke of York, later King James II, who was married to Hyde's sister, Anne, he received several important political appointments. He was, for most of his career, a supporter of the Stuart side against the claims of William of Orange for the English throne. Subsequently, and for reasons that are disputed, he abandoned that position and came over to the side of William. In 1666, Hyde married Flower Backhouse, his second wife. Her family was in possession of the Swallowfield Park estate in Berkshire.
Charles Knyvett was an organist and choral singer at Westminster Abbey. He was named a Gentleman of the Chapel Royal in 1786, in which capacity he served as organist, singer, and composer.

person.persName: Elizabeth Anne LeNoir LeNoir Smart Elizabeth Anne
person.note: The daughter of Christopher Smart, and step-granddaughter of John Newbery, LeNoir grew up in Ireland but subsequently moved with her family to Readingin 1762. After her father's imprisonment for debt and death, her grandfather employed her as a writer and editor at the Reading Mercury. On John Newbery's death, she, together with her mother and her sister, Mary Anne Cowslade, later inherited partial ownership of the periodical. She married French emigre, Jean Baptiste LeNoir de la Brosse in 1795. Between 1803 and 1825, LeNoir published five novels and one book of poetry. The novels contain original poetry, and are frequently set in rural scenes. Mitford admired her works, mentioning them in Recollections of a Literary Life, where she says that she is personally acquainted with LeNoir's nieces. In Nutting, Mitford praises her fourth novel, The Maid of La Vendee.
Biography of Elizabeth LeNoir by Laura Ridley. Corvey 'Adopt an Author'

person.persName: Earl Liverpool Jenkinson Robert Banks Earl of Liverpool Prime Minister of the United Kingdom Secretary of State for War and the Colonies Leader of the House of Lords Home Secretary Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs
person.note: Tory politican who served as Prime Minister between 1807 and 1827. His administration was notable for the repressive measures taken before and after the Peterloo massacre, as well its controversial attempts to stabilize the economy after the the battle of Waterloo.

person.persName:
George Lyttleton Lyttelton George
1st Baron Lyttelton Sir George Lyttelton, 5th Baronet
person.note: Whig Member of Parliament for Okehampton between 1735 and 1756, Lyttelton held several political positions, including Chancellor of the Exchecquer from 1755 to 1756. He was also a poet and patron of artists and other poets, praised by Alexander Pope, and the dedicatee of Tom Jones. While his own works were generally published in edited anthologies, during the nineteenth century, he was chiefly remembered for his elegies written for his first wife.

Comedic actor known for his roles in the plays of William Congreve, Shakespeare, and Susanna Centlivre. His comic reputation followed him posthumously with the publication of Joe Miller's Jests, a book of jokes that was not by him, but that associated his name with into posterity.
A greyhound dog that Mitford received from Mrs. Newell after the death of her husband in October 1816.

Widely considered the most influential publisher of children's books of his time, Newbery began his career as a printer's apprentice in Reading, working for the founder of the Reading Mercury, William Carnan. He later married Carnan's widow, and adopted her three children. In 1744, he moved his business to St. Paul's Churchyard, London, and opened the Juvenile Library, recruiting well-known authors to produce children's books that would change the face of children's literature. Some of Newbery's notable works include A Little Pretty Pocket Book, The History of Margery Two-Shoes and The Liliputian Magazine. Newbery's sons and newphew carried on the business after his death. His step-daughter, Anna Maria Smart and step-granddaughter, Mary Anne Cowslade continued operating the Reading Mercury. His second step-granddaughter, Elizabeth LeNoir became a novelist.
Friend of the Mitfords who operated a farm in Whitby Park. He may be the inspiration for the farmer in A Great Farmhouse. His forename is unidentified.
Friend of the Mitfords who is likely the inspiration for the farmer's wife featured in A Great Farmhouse. Her forename and paternal surname are unidentified.

Commonly known as Old Parr, Thomas Parr became something of a celebrity due to his claim to be near 150-years old. After his death, an autopsy found that he was likely closer to seventy years old. He is buried in Westminster Abbey.

persName.roleName: Lieutenant of the Duchy of Aquitaine

person.note: Henry Percy was knighted by King Edward III, and held important military and administrative positions during the reigns of Richard II and Henry IV. His nickname, Hotspur, was reportedly given to him by his Scottish opponents when he fought against them during Richard II's campaigns on the Borders. Though he initially had favor with Henry IV, he developed a number of grievances against him, including anger at Henry's refusal to ransom Percy's brother-in-law who had been captured by the Scottish. He eventually organized a rebellion, and was killed at the Battle of Shrewsbury under disputed circumstances. Shakespeare's Henry IV Part 1 created the legend that Prince Hal killed him in hand-to-hand combat. It is the first recorded battle using the English longbow on English soil.

Charles Perrault is today best known as the inventor of the modern fairy tale. Born into a wealthy family, Perrault spent his career as a secretary in the Academy of Inscriptions and Belles-Lettres. He also worked in various capacities within the court of Louis XIV to promote the King's projects. He was a prominent advocate for the Modern side in the debate between the Ancients and the Moderns in excellence in the arts, and a distinguished art critic. In 1671, he was elected to the Academie francaise. After he was forcibly retired from the court by one of his rivals and denied his government pension, he turned to writing. He published an epic poem, then, in 1697 composed a collection of fairy tales under the name of his youngest son, Pierre Darmancourt, entitled Tales and Stories of the Past with Morals. This collection of stories, drawn from previous literary collections and from French folk tales, featured tales that became classics, such as Little Red Riding Hood, Cinderella; or the Little Glass Slipper, Bluebeard, and Sleeping Beauty. The volume went through numerous editions, translations, and adaptations. By Mitford's time, Perrault's tales were recognized and published as stories for children, despite their sometimes racy themes.

person.persName:
Victoire de Donissan de Lescure de la Rochejacquelein de la Rochejacquelein de Lescure de Donissan Marie-Louise-Victoire marquise de Lescure
marquise douaniere de Lescure
marquise douaniere de Lescure, comtesse de la Rochejacquelein
marquise douaniere de Lescure, marquise de la Rochejacquelein
marquise douaniere de Lescure et de la Rochejacquelein
person.note: French aristocrat of the Revolutionary period whose autobiography, Memoire de Madame de la marquise de la Rochejacquelein, recounts her harrowing escape from Paris during the Revolution, and her subsequent sufferings through the Vendeean uprisings, during which she lost her first husband, Louis Marie de Salgue, the marquis de Lescure. She later married his cousin, Louis du Vergier de la Rochejacquelein, and together they continued to advocate for royalist ascendancy in France.
Italian Baroque painter, known chiefly for extravagant, jagged, and dark landscapes. He was much admired by the Romantics as a rebel for his unorthodox subject-matter.

person.persName: Sir Henry Russell, first baronet Russell Henry
person.note: Sir Henry Russell, the first baronet, purchased Swallowfield Park in 1820. Having begun his career as a lawyer, he was appointed to the supreme court of judicature in Bengal in 1798. He later ascended to become chief justice of the Bengal supreme court. He was created a baronet in 1812, and returned to England, after which he was made a member of the Privy Council. When he purchased the Swallowfield Park estate, he began extensive renovations. Mitford was acquainted with the family.

person.persName: Sir Henry Russell, second baronet Russell Henry
person.note: Son of Sir Henry Russell, first baronet of Swallowfield, who inherited the Swallowfield Park estate upon his father's death. When he was fourteen-years old, he accompanied his father to India, where he began working his way up through the diplomatic ranks in Hyderabad, becoming Secretary to James Achilles Kirkpatrick, and then succeeding him as British Resident. He remained in India after his father retired, working in the Resident position. In 1815, he fathered a daughter, Mary Wilson, with a local Indian woman, and though he provided for her financially, he never acknowledged her or allowed her to know who her father was. He married Marie-Clotilde Mottet de la Fontaine in 1816. He finally gave up the Residency and returned to England in 1820 to avoid being removed for corruption. After his return to England and the death of his father, he fell out of the life of a civil servant, and set about renovating the Swallowfield Park estate. One of his notable alterations was to fill up the canal that had run between the Lock Pool and the Bow Bridge. In addition, he had built two new bridges. Mitford was a friend of the family, particularly later in her life.

person.persName: Lady Marie-Clotilde Russell Russell Mottet de la Fontaine Marie-Clotilde
person.note: Lady Marie-Clotilde Russell was the wife of Sir Henry Russell, the second baronet of Swallowfield Place, whom she met and married while he was stationed in India. She was the daughter of the police-director and colonial prefect of the French territory in India of Pondicherry. She returned with Henry Russell to England in 1820. The couple had six children, the fourth one, Charles, succeeding his father to the baronetcy. Settling at Swallowfield Place, Lady Russell developed a close friendship with Mitford in the latter part of her life, and was with her when she died.
Swallowfield and Its Owners by Lady Constance Russell

Whig Member of Parliament who represented the borough of Reading for several years, fighting a number of contested elections. He was acquainted with the Mitford family, and they socialized in the early part of the nineteenth century. Mitford's nickname for him was Gog. He may be the local Member of Parliament mentioned in A Great Farmhouse, whose estates are managed by the farmer.

Christopher Smart was a prolific writer and translator of religious, lyrical, and satirical verse. He was an acquaintance of Alexander Pope (whose Ode to St. Cecilia Smart translated into Latin), Samuel Johnson, and William Collins, all of whom expressed admiration for his work. After attending Cambridge and becoming praelector of Philosophy and keeper of the common chest in 1745, Smart began to write poetry and plays, but also to accumulate debts that would follow him for the rest of his life. He began contributing to the magazine The Student under the pseudonym Ebenezer Pentweazle. As a result of debt and a struggle with mental illness, he lost his place at Cambridge. Smart had met and married the step-daughter of John Newbery. Newbery at the time was part-owner with his wife of the Reading Mercury. Newbery employed Smart to produce material for his publishing and advertising ventures, including a periodical entitled The Midwife; or the Old Woman's Magazine. Newbery also published Smart's first major work, Poems on Several Occasions, which included his lengthy georgic, The Hop Garden. Smart also produced a prose translation of Horace's works. In 1763, Smart again suffered an episode of mental illness which took the form of a sort of religious mania, and he was confined to an asylum. During his confinement, he composed his most famous works, Song to David and Jubilate Agno. He died in the King's Bench Prison, where he had been imprisoned for debt. His widow, Anna Maria Smart and daughter, Mary Anne Cowslade continued to operate the Reading Mercury for several decades after his death, while his second daughter, Elizabeth LeNoir became a novelist.
Considered the founder of Western philosophy, Socrates' teachings in moral, ethical, and political thought were disseminated through the writings of his students, most prominently Plato and Xenophon.

Born to a minister father, Thomson grew up in Southdean, and was educated in Jedburgh and later the University of Edinburgh. He intended a life in the ministry, but after university, he went to London to pursue a literary career. The work that made him famous was The Seasons, a long four-part poem that contemplated the works of nature in meditative blank verse. He also collaborated to write plays and lyrics, including the lyrics to Rule, Britannia!. Thomson's final eduring work was The Castle of Indolence.
David Teniers the younger was a prominent Flemish artist, known for many styles. He is noted for his landscapes and peasant paintings that featured rustic characters in sociable settings.

person.persName: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y Velazquez Rodriguez de Silva Velazquez Diego
person.note: Spanish Golden Age painter who worked at the court of King Phillip IV. He was known for his portraits of Spanish royalty and members of the court, as well as peasants occupied with daily tasks. His realistic style utilized the tenebrist contrast of light and dark.

Oxford Professor of Poetry, literary historian and critic, and Poet Laureate from 1785 to 1790. Warton (often called the younger) is best remembered for his contributions to the Graveyard School of poetry, including The Pleasures of Melancholy.

roleName.date: Member of the House of Lords

person.note: Elder son of the First Duke of Wellington, who succeeded his father to the dukedom, and became Member of Parliament for Aldeburgh, and later for Norwich.

persName.roleName: Member of Parliament for Hampshire Southern 1842-1852

person.note: Second son of the first Duke of Wellington. He grew up to serve as Chief Equerry and Clerk Marshall to Queen Victoria, and later entered Parliament. Both of his sons succeeded his brother, Arthur Wellesley, jr., to the Wellington dukedom.

English politician and a leader of the movement to stop the slave trade. He began his political career in 1780. Wilberforce was elected an independent Member of Parliament for Yorkshire and became an Evangelical Christian in 1785, resulting in major lifestyle changes and a lifelong concern for reform. He funded various literary activities aimed at encouraging moral reform among the poor. In 1787, he contacted anti-slave trade activists such as Thomas Clarkson, Granville Sharp, Hannah More, and Charles Middleton, who persuased him to join the abolitionist cause, and to introduce a bill in Parliament. He did so regularly without success until 1807, with the Abolition of the Slave Trade Act, which abolished England's participation in the trade. Wilberforce retired from Parliament in 1824, but continued working for a total abolition of slavery in the empire. He died three days after the third reading of the Abolition of Slavery bill.
Welsh artist whose work popularized the aesthetic possibilities of landscape painting. He is considered one of the most important Welsh artists.

person.persName: William the Conqueror William the Conqueror William the Bastard
person.note: The first Norman king of England, William was the illegitimate son of Robert I of Normandy and his mistress. Nevertheless, he succeeded to his father's estate and, after consolidating his power, undertook an invasion of England to assert his claim to be King Edward the Confessor's successor. At the Battle of Hastings, William defeated his rival, Harold Godwinson, and assumed the throne. William spent most of his reign in Normandy, leaving the daily oversight of England to his administrators. One of his notable acts was seeing to the creation of the Domesday Book, which is a survey of all English landholders and their lands.

Woollett was a skilled engraver who became engraver-in-ordinary to King George III. As part of his process, he used engraving, dry-point, and etching, and influenced what became known as a British school of engraving. He was known for producing varieties of subjects, from historical to mythological to landscape scenes. His works are catalogued in A Catalogue Raisonne of the Works of William Woollett.

org.note: The group of characters mentioned in Aunt Martha who call for the title character to help them with their lyings-in.

The family with whom Aunt Martha lives in Aunt Martha. While they are unnamed in the sketch, it has been suggested that they are the fictional counterparts of James Webb's family, all of whom were close friends of Mitford. The sketch mentions two daughters, but the Webbs had three: James Webb, Jane, Eliza, and Mary.
In Aunt Martha, these are the title character's two nieces in whose household she lives. These characters may the fictional counterparts of two of the Webb girls, Mary, Eliza, or Jane.
The followers of the Roman deity, Bacchus, the god of wine.
Part of the crowd gathered at the Maying at Bramley in Bramley Maying.

A farming family featured in Nutting. The family includes the parents and five children. They are observed harvesting their pear and apple trees.

The opposing cricket team in A Country Cricket Match. Usually in Our Village, the initial B. designates Reading, but in this sketch, it refers to a parish to the nortwest of the narrator's own. Location as yet unidentified.
The rival cricket team from the parish of S. mentioned in A Country Cricket Match.
Young women, mentioned in A Country Cricket Match, who attend genteel cricket matches in distinction from the robust country affairs Mitford describes in this sketch.

The spectators of the cricket match in A Country Cricket Match. In the story, the narrator praises the spectators of such rural games over gentleman sportsmen, among them mothers, young girls and boys, and retired, amateur cricketers.
Groups of men, mentioned in A Country Cricket Match, who attend cricket matches at genteel locales such as Lord's Cricket Ground.
The Shinfield parish cricket team featured in A Country Cricket Match.
The gentlemen who bet on cricketing, including players, mentioned in A Country Cricket Match.
Group of young men in A Country Cricket Match who persuade their peers and local authorities to resurrect cricket play in the parish.
The magistrates, mentioned in A Country Cricket Match, who permit the resumption of cricket in the parish.
The accomplished and educated daughters of the friends whom the Our Village narrator is visiting in . Their names are not given.
The family whom the Our Village narrator is visiting when she meets Mary C., the title character of .

org.orgName: the climbing party in Cousin Mary
org.note: The group of young women who climb The Ridges in Cousin Mary.
Servants who are mentioned assisting the climbing party in Cousin Mary.
Boys who mimic the cuckoo bird in The Cowslip Ball.
The school that is supported by Mrs. Frances and Mrs. Theodosia in Modern Antiques.
The family who lives in the great house at F. Hill whom the narrator and her friend call on in The Visit.
Three one-eyed suitors of Lucy in the sketch, Lucy.

The Martins are three farmers who present themselves to play on the Shinfield cricket team in A Country Cricket Match, but they are rejected for their lack of skills in the game. Their forenames are not given.

These characters are mentioned in the sketch Mrs. Mosse. They are said to be six young ladies who once contributed to the purchase of Sir Charles Grandison for the lending library so they could circulate the book among themselves.
These characters are mentioned in the sketch Mrs. Mosse as servants in the Mitford household who take advantage of the title character in her old age.
Character mentioned in Mrs. Mosse. They are among the many visitors to Mitford's maternal grandmother's home.
Character mentioned in Mrs. Mosse. They are among the many visitors to Mitford's maternal grandmother's home.

These characters are mentioned in the sketch Mrs. Mosse as servants in the Mitford household who are dismissed for taking advantage of the title character in her old age.
This set of characters, participants in a smallpox inoculation party at the home of Mitford's maternal grandfather, appear in Mrs. Mosse, and include his second wife.
These characters are mentioned in Mrs. Mosse as servants in the Mitford household who take advantage of the title character in her old age.
These characters are mentioned in Mrs. Mosse. They attend the smallpox inoculation party that includes the second wife of Mitford's maternal grandfather.
Character mentioned in Mrs. Mosse. They are among the many visitors to Mitford's maternal grandmother's home.
These characters are mentioned in the sketch Mrs. Mosse. They are sent away during the smallpox innoculation party that includes the second wife of Mitford's maternal grandfather.
These characters are mentioned in Mrs. Mosse. They are the sisters of the second wife of Mitford's maternal grandfather who populate the household.
These characters are not literally seen, but recalled as ones that the narrator would expect to meet on her walk in Nutting.
Group of bricklayers who work on the home renovations of the wealthy renovator in Our Village.
The group of carpenters who work on the home renovations of the wealthy renovator in Our Village.
Group of small boys who play games amongst themselves during a cricket match in Our Village.
Group of cricketers observed in Our Village.

The nuclear family of the Our Village narrator, which consists of herself, her father, and her mother, closely mirroring the Mitfords. The family is not always directly specified, and will often be referred to as we and our when the narrator speaks.
Friends of the Our Village narrator mentioned in Bramley Maying, unidentified in the text, who lose their way, and fail to arrive at the Maying.
Group of workmen who employed on the the home renovations of the wealthy renovator in Our Village.
Various horsemen who are observed riding through the town in Our Village.
Guests at the annual Christmas party of Mr. Sidney, the protagonist of An Old Bachelor.

org.orgName: competitors of Mr. Sidney at whist
org.note: The assorted characters with whom Mr. Sidney plays whist in An Old Bachelor.
A group of spectators who watch the cricket match mentioned in Our Village.

org.orgName: Red Lion Inn in Tom Cordery
org.note: The inn at which Tom holds court in Tom Cordery.
The daughter and son of Sir W.S., for whom Mary C. goes to work as a governess in Cousin Mary.

London hospital, founded in 1751, to treat the mentally ill. It was initially intended for paupers, but by Mitford's time was ministering to the middle classes. Treatments frequently included purgatives, cold baths, and emetics. In Our Village, John Evans is said to have been committed there after the death of his wife.
The party of friends who meet Harry L. in Windsor in The Talking Gentleman. This group includes the narrator.
Characters mentioned in The Talking Gentleman who are said to be charmed by Harry L.'s wit.
The medical men who advise their patients to avoid Harry L., because his wit and talkativeness are dangerous to their health.
Characters mentioned in The Talking Gentleman who are advised by their doctors to avoid Harry L.because his wit and talkativeness are deemed dangerous to their health.
The mail passengers who share the coach with the title character of The Talking Lady when she departs from her visit. They include a civil young man, his mother, and a grumpy man.

org.orgName: boys and girls in The Visit
org.note: Boys and girls whom the narrator observes collecting beech-nuts in The Visit.
Old women whom the narrator observes collecting twigs and acorns in The Visit.
Younger children whom the narrator observes collecting dead leaves in The Visit.

org.orgName: keepers of the game on M. Common
org.note: Keepers of game on M. Common who are mentioned in Tom Cordery. Although they are enforcers of game laws, Tom is on good terms with them.

Various groups mentioned throughout Tom Cordery as people who enlist the title character's services for hare-finding on the commons. These groups consist of small gentry,, great farmers, farmers, and squires. Tom often takes them on futile searches into barren areas.
Group of wealthy proprietors mentioned in Tom Cordery who have enclosed their lands.
Two hanged men whose execution took place at the Gallows Piece. The story is told to the narrator by the title character of Tom Cordery.
Mentioned in Tom Cordery as people who love the title character.
Mentioned in Tom Cordery as people who love the title character.
The workhouse where Tom and his wife are moved in Tom Cordery.
The children who live in the workhouse in the sketch Tom Cordery. Tom finds them bothersome.
The workhouse population whom Tom finds bothersome in Tom Cordery.
The women and children who are observed at their labor of beansetting in Violeting.
The women beansetters who are described in Violeting.
The children who are observed playing by the pond in Violeting.
Part of the laboring group that includes the beansetters in Violeting.
In Violeting, the narrator facetiously imagines these characters standing up to the madcap lord of the manor to prevent an enclosure in Shinfield parish.
Part of the laboring group that includes the beansetters in Violeting.
The children in the workhouse yard observed in Violeting.

The characters riding on the inside of the coach who are observed by the narrator during the heatwave in The Hard Summer. They consist of the large gentleman, an overheated young boy, his mother, and a pale girl.
The characters riding on the outside of the coach who are observed by the narrator during the heatwave in The Hard Summer.
The group of young local boys whose cricket match the narrator stops to watch in The Hard Summer. The players include Jem Eusden, Joe Kirby, and the little hussar.
Characters mentioned in The First Primrose. They are the fourteen children of the amiable Rachel and Joseph White.

org.orgName: boys at the Our Village illumination
org.note: A group of young boys, mentioned in Our Village who enthusiastically participate in the illumination organized by the retired publican in celebration of Queen Caroline's acquittal.
The three journeymen who work for the village shoemaker. They are mentioned in Our Village.
Characters from the Arabian Nights tale of The Porter and the Three Ladies. Also known as dervishes.
The local parish workhouse mentioned in several Our Village sketches, including Our Village, Violeting, and The First Primrose.
Group of girls in red cloaks observed by the narrator on her walk in Frost.
Group of small landowners in and around Three Mile Cross who allow foot traffic on their lands. They are mentioned in The Cowslip Ball.

The large array of relations enumerated by the narrator who have pre-deceased the title character of The Talking Lady, and whose lives she can discuss in great detail. They include her grandfather, her great-grandfather, some nephews, her grand-nephew, her father, her mother, her brother, her sister, her uncle, and a niece. Some of these people, the narrator implies, were those she lived with and talked to death.
The village church in Three Mile Cross as represented in Our Village.

person.note: In Greek mythology, Achilles was the son of the nereid Thetis and King Peleus of Phthia in Thessaly. While he was an infant, a prophesy foretold that he would either gain glory and die young, or die old without fame, so he chose the former. His mother sought to protect him from harm by dipping him in the River Styx, leaving only his ankles untouched by the waters. He is essentially the hero of the Trojan War and The Iliad, though he died in that war after avenging his friend, Patroclus.
Roman goddess of wild animals and the hunt.
One of the three Charites or Graces in ancient Greek religion. She is the daughter of Zeus, a Goddess of Joy or Mirth, and the incarnation of grace and beauty.

Goliath is the Philistine giant that the future King David of Israel slays with a sling. The term David and Goliath has come to represent an underdog situation in which the underdog is victorious. Goliath is also representative of Christ's defeat of Satan in the New Testament as the Philistines represent paganism, and King David is one of the anscestors of Jesus Christ in Christianity. The story of David and Goliath is found in 1 Samuel 17. The story is important Biblically as it is David's defeat of Goliath that leads King Saul to appoint David as head of the Israelite army, leading to David's ascension to the Israelite throne.
The mother of Moses, Aaron, and Miriam in the Old Testament.
King of the gods in ancient Roman and Greek religions, he controls the sky and the thunder. In Rome, he was known as Jove and Jupiter, while in Greece, he was called Zeus.
In Greek mythology, Medusa is a Gorgon with snakes for hair. A glimpse of her face will turn the onlooker to stone.

The prophet of Judaic and Christian traditions who was chosen by God to lead the enslaved Israelites out of Egypt, and who delivered the Ten Commandments to the people, building a covenant between them and God. After forty years wandering in the desert, Moses led his people to the promised land of Canaan, but was himself not allowed to enter.

In ancient Greek and Roman mythology, Pan is the god of shepherds and their flocks, as well as of rustic fields and groves. He is generally represented with a faun's legs and a human torso, frequently playing a flute.

In Roman mythology and literature, Psyche is a human woman whose beauty caused the jealousy of Venus, who sentenced her to be wed to a sea monster. Rather than allow this to happen, Cupid rescues her and takes her as his wife while forbidding her to see him. Worried that she is married to a monster, Psyche secretly lights a lamp, but some oil burns Cupid's skin. Cupid abandons her, and Psyche is forced to search the world for him, and complete difficult tasks for Venus until they are reunited.
Character mentioned in The First Primrose. She is the wife of a gardener who sometimes worked for the narrator's family , and lives separately from her.
Character introduced in the First Primrose. He is a gardener who worked for the narrator's family,the husband of Betty Adams, but he lives in a different town. Forename not given.

Character from A Country Cricket Match. She is the love-interest of James Brown whose plea for him to come to play for her town's team prevents him from participating in the Shinfield match against the team from B.. She is from the town of M..
Character who serves as the main servant to Mr. Sidney in An Old Bachelor, and acts on behalf of the household owner. Forename not given.
Character appearing in A Country Cricket Match. He is the sixth player chosen for the Shinfield cricket team, and is distinguished for his good humor.
Character who appears in the sketch Tom Cordery. We learn that Tom thoroughly defeated him in a fight.
Character of the housekeeper mentioned in Aunt Martha.
The beloved patriarch of the household in which Aunt Martha lives in Aunt Martha. He may be the fictionalized portrait of James Webb, but that is speculative. Name not given.
The peddler and thief who appears in Shakespeare's The Winter's Tale.
Character mentioned in The First Primrose. She is the wife of Mr. Barnard, a wealthy farmer. Forename not given.
Character mentioned in The First Primrose. He is the adopted nephew of of farmer Barnard and his wife, who have no children of their own. Name not given.
Character mentioned in The First Primsrose. He is a wealthy farmer who lives near the narrator. Forename not given.

In Bramley Maying, the unidentified character who accompanies the narrator to the Maying. From the character's description in the text, the person could be the narrator's father, who is based on George Mitford. Name not given.
In Bramley Maying, he is the character who provides the narrator and her companion with the key to the church when they arrive in Bramley. Name not given.
In Bramley Maying, he is the character who guides the narrator and her companion on a tour of the Bramley church. Name not given.
A character selling fruits whom the narrator encounters in Bramley Maying. Name not given.
In the Bramley Maying, this character attends the Maying rather than attending to visitors of the church. Name not given.

Character mentioned in A Country Cricket Match as the farmer for whom Joel Brent works. He succumbs to social pressure and allows Joel to join the Shinfield cricket team and play in the match against the team from B. rather than bringing in the hay harvest. Name not given.
A character in The Faerie Queene by Edmund Spenser. She is a female knight who embodies chastity.
This character appears in the sketch Nutting. He farms an apple and pear orchard together with his large family. Forename not given.
This character appears in Nutting, in which she is seen at the fruit harvest with her family. Forename not given.

This character appears in Nutting at the fruit harvest with his family, and later gathers nuts with the narrator. He is said to be about six- or seven-years old, and the narrator imagines him betrothed to Lizzy.
This young girl appears in Nutting, where she is seen happily gathering the apples that her older brother flings down from a tree. Forename not given.
This character appears in Nutting, in which he is shown climbing to the top of a pear-tree and shaking down the fruit during the harvest. Forename not given.
This character appears in Nutting, where he is seen pelting apples down from a tree at his younger sister during the harvest. Forename not given.
This character, an infant, is observed in Nutting eating some of the harvested fruit. Forename not given.
Character who appears in A Country Cricket Match. He is the married brother of James Brown, with whom the latter has come to reside after six years as a journeyman blacksmith. Forename not given.

Character who appears in A Country Cricket Match. She is the wife of James Brown's brother, and sister-in-law to James Brown. She is the one who delivers the letter from Mary Allen to James, which leads him to abandon the match. Forename not given.

Character who appears in A Country Cricket Match. After traveling as a journeyman blacksmith for six years, he has returned to Shinfield, where he is commended as the best cricket player on the Shinfield cricket team. His secret relationship with Mary Allen from a neighboring town leads him to abscond from playing the match against the team from B.. Notes from Francis Needham's archives suggest that a blacksmith named Benjamin Brown may have served as the model for this character.

Suitor and later husband of Lucy. The real life counterpart of this character is Charles Hill, who married the real life Lucy Sweetser. He appears in several Our Village sketches, notably Lucy and Bramley Maying.
A hunting dog mentioned in Nutting.
Character in Emma who flirts with the title character.
Character who appears in A Country Cricket Match. He is one of the Shinfield cricketers, and is considered a good batter. He is also mentioned in The Hard Summer.
The wife of Tom Cordery in the story of the same name Forename not given.
Title character of Tom Cordery. Despite being a tricky and unreliable hunting guide for local gentlemen, as well as a well-known poacher, he is liked and admired in the area.
Character who appears in A Country Cricket Match. His alliance with the high church curate enables the renewal of cricket in Shinfield. Name not given.
Character who appears in A Country Cricket Match. His alliance with the evangelical farmer enables the renewal of cricket in Shinfield. Name not given.
Character who appears in A Country Cricket Match. He, along with the Rose Inn Landlord, donates ribbons for the cricket games. Name not given.
Character who appears in A Country Cricket Match. She is a child thief who steals the handkerchief of Samuel Long after the match. Name not given.
The umpire who appears in A Country Cricket Match. Name not given.
The twelve-year old daughter of Sir W.S. in Cousin Mary. Forename and full surname not given.
The seven-year old son of Sir W.S. in Cousin Mary. Forename and full surname not given.
Character appearing in Cousin Mary, whom the title character helps climb the Ridges. Name not given.
She is the mostly deaf grandmother of Sally Wheeler who lives with her granddaughter. Forename not given.
Character featured in Ellen. She is the nurse of Charlotte and Ellen Page. Name not given.
One of the country boys who plays a skillful game of cricket in The Hard Summer. He is said to be about 13-years old, and is a rival of Joe Kirby.
This character appears in The Visit. She is the infant daughter of the friend from F. Hill whom the narrator visits. She is the fictional counterpart of Frances Dickinson. Surname not given.
Character who appears in The Visit accompanying his daughters as they sing and play during a call on the great house. Name not given.
This character, who is mentioned in The Visit, is based on Charles Dickinson. Name not given.

person.persName: sister of the F. Hill friend
person.note: In The Visit, this character is referred to as the sister of the F. Hill friend who accompanies her as she sings. Name not given.
This character, who appears in The Visit, hosts the narrator at her home in F. Hill. She is based on Mitford's friend, Catherine Dickinson. Name not given.
A character who appears in The Visit.
Character in Emma who has little money or prospects.
Character who appears in Ellen. He is the father of Miss Falkner and William Falkner. Forename not given.
Character from the Our Village sketch Ellen. She is the sister of Colonel Falkner and the sister-in-law of Ellen Page. Forename not given.
Character featured in Ellen. He is the brother of Miss Falkner and becomes the husband of Ellen Page.
Character from Shakespeare's Henry IV part 1 who serves as page to Falstaff. His later life unfolds in Henry V.
A character in The Faerie Queene by Edmund Spenser. She is the nurse of Britomartwho dresses as a man to accompany her charge on her quest.

Welsh rebel hero of legend and history, a version of whom features in Shakespeare's Henry IV, Part 1. In the play, he is depicted as a wild man who claims to be able to call up spirits, and it is in this Shakespearean sense that Mitford generally refers to him.

Unnamed Member of Parliament mentioned in A Great Farmhouse, whose estates are managed by the farmer. Given the timing of the narrator's recollections, and the fact that this sketch has origins in an 1816 letter, it is possible that the Member of Parliament referred to is Charles Shaw-Lefevre, who at that time was representing Reading.

The jovial farmer who is recalled in A Great Farmhouse. The character is not named, but letter evidence suggests that Mitford is recalling her friend Mr. Newell of Whitby Park farm, who died in October 1816. After his death, Mitford was given one his greyhounds, Nell. See letter to Mary Webb dated October 28, 1816.
Son of the farming couple whom Mitford recollects with fondness in A Great Farmhouse. Name not given.
The character of the farmer's wife in A Great Farmhouse. This character is not named, but letter evidence suggests that Mitford is recalling her friends, the Newells of Whitby Park.

Character who appears in several Our Village sketches, but most prominently in A Country Cricket Match, where he is the captain of the cricket team who also organizes the team's players. He is noted as a rival of Joel Brent in A Village Beau, and is also mentioned in The Hard Summer.

Character who appears in A Country Cricket Match. Grover, known as a man of good judgment, acts as a spy on the B. parish cricket team to report on the team's skills. He also brings the news that Joel Brent cannot participate in the match.
By the end of Our Village, 1st series, she is the new servant for the Our Village narrator's family, replacing Lucy. She is the fictional counterpart of Harriet Keep. Surname not given.
Character who appears in A Country Cricket Match. He is the seventh man chosen for the cricket team.

Character mentioned in A Country Cricket Match. He is the father-in-law of Joseph Hearne, and the man with whom the latter lodges, making him eligible to play on the Shinfield cricket team. Name not given.

Character in A Country Cricket Match. He works at the A. Mills in a neighboring parish, but lodges in Shinfield parish at the home of his father-in-law. Despite being an excellent cricket player, his hesitancy about playing on the Shinfield cricket team in their match against the B. parish team leads him to be rejected for play by William Grey.
In Greek mythology, Hebe is the goddess of youth, as well as a cupbearer for the gods. She is the daughter of Zeus and Hera, and is married to Heracles.

The Greek mythological queen whose abduction sparked the Trojan War. She is depicted in many literary works such as The Iliad and The Odyssey. She is also the titular character in Euripides's play Helen.
Character mentioned in The First Primrose. He is the father of Rachel White. Forename not given.

In Shakespeare's history play Henry IV Part 1, he is a main character, a rebel against the king who is killed by Prince Hal. He, as well as the events depicted in the play, is based on the real-life Sir Henry Percy and the rebellion he led against King Henry IV.
Character mentioned in The Visit. He is a local boy, the brother of Joe Kirby.
A pleasant young cricket player who appears in The Hard Summer and The Visit. He is a friend of the narrator. It is possible that this character was based on a real-life Joseph Kirby.

person.persName: Sarah Kirby from Our Village Kirby not given Sarah Mrs.
person.note: Mother of Ben Kirby and Joe Kirby who appears in several Our Village sketches.

person.persName: Harry L. L. Henry Harry Major
person.note: The titular protagonist of The Talking Gentleman. In this portrait, Harry is described as an energetic jovial, witty man who, despite being an incessant talker, is a beloved well-known local personality. His last name is not given in full.
The wife of Harry L. in the sketch The Talking Gentleman. She is unnamed in the sketch, and all readers learn about her is that she has property in Devonshire. Forename not given.

The lady is mentioned in Bramley Maying, and is likely a reference to Harriot Brocas, wife of Bernard Brocas, who was known to spend little time at their newly renovated estate, Beaurepaire House, after her husband's death, prefering to stay at Wokefield Park.
One of Lucy's more noteworthy lovers who is mentioned in Lucy. He was not a part of the group of three lovers. A talented tailor, he left Lucy after she consented to marry him.
Character mentioned in A Country Cricket Match. She is the mother of Samuel Long, and the maker of the handkerchief that is stolen. Forename not given.

A character who appears in several Our Village sketches. He is one of the Shinfield cricket team in A Country Cricket Match. He is a middle-aged man, a day-laborer, who has recently moved back to Shinfield from S. parish. He is known as a good bowler. He also appears in The Visit.

person.persName:
Lucy Lucy
Title character Lucy. She is a beloved servant in the narrator's household who leaves town after her marriage. She is based on Lucy Sweetser Hill, whose marriage to Charles Hill in 1820 led to her move to Silchester to teach school. She appears or is mentioned in several stories, notably Hannah and A Visit to Lucy. Her paternal last name is not given.

person.note: Character mentioned in Lucy as someone the protagonist has spoken to. It is possible that Mrs. Smith is Hannah Wilson Smith from Hannah.
One of Lucy's three one-eyed lovers, the most prominent of the group, who courted her for ten years.

Character in Sir Walter Scott's A Legend of Montrose. As someone who was adopted as a young child, her parentage is obscure throughout much of the novel, and as a result, the two men who love her and violently compete for her are reluctant to marry her. She is represented as an excellent singer and harp player.

Character who appears in Bramley Maying. He is the butcher of the village of M. who gives the narrator and her companion complicated directions to the Maying after they have lost their way. Name not given.
Character who appears in Bramley Maying. He gives the narrator and her companion directions to the Maying, and later accompanies them on part of their journey. Name not given.
In the Robin Hood legends, Maid Marian is the hero's paramour.

Title character of Aunt Martha, who is described as a beloved unmarried member of a a gentleman and his daughters' household. Francis Needham speculates that she is a fictionalized portrait of Mary Webb, but this seems unlikely. Surname not given.
The deceased father of Cousin Mary in the sketch Cousin Mary. Name not given.
Mother of the title character in Cousin Mary, who is admired for giving her daughter a natural education with no accomplishments. Forename and full surname not given.
Sister of the title character of Cousin Mary, with whom Mary lives before becoming a governess. She is a notorious matchmaker. Name not given.
Title character from the Our Village sketch Cousin Mary. She is raised without accomplishments and is beloved by all. Surname not given in full.
In Shakespeare's play, The Merry Wives of Windsor, Slender is a foolish character whom Anne Page tricks as part of the larger trick on Falstaff.
One of the young women vying for Joel Brent's hand in marriage. She speaks badly of anyone she considers a rival.
Character mentioned in A Village Beau. He is the brother of Sophia Matthews and works as a collar-maker. Forename not given.
Character mentioned in A Village Beau. He is the late father of Sophia Matthews, who worked as a collar-maker. Forename not given.
One of two serving maids mentioned in Modern Antiques who works for Mrs. Frances and Mrs. Theodosia. She is made to represent several young women who leave their employment.
One of two serving maids who work for Mrs. Frances and Mrs. Theodosia. She is older than the first maid, and is said to resemble her employers.
The brother of Mrs. Frances and Mrs. Theodosia mentioned in Modern Antiques. Name not given.
Character mentioned in Modern Antiques who prevents either Mrs. Frances or Mrs. Theodosia from being blown away in a strong wind.

The title character of the Mrs. Mosse. In the sketch, Mossy is recalled as an elderly servant, based on the real Elizabeth Cropp, who worked in the household of Dr. Richard Russell before he married Mary Russell.
Character mentioned in Lucy as the owner of a fir plantation near where Lucy lives in the town of S.
Half-nephew and natural heir of Mrs. Mosse. He and his wife are said to live in Prince's Street, Barbican. Forename not given.
Half-niece by marriage of Mrs. Mosse. She and her husband are said to live in Prince's Street, Barbican. Forename not given.
Character mentioned in Mrs. Mosse. She is among the many visitors to Mitford's maternal grandmother's home. Name not given.
Character mentioned in Mrs. Mosse. He is among the many visitors to Mitford's maternal grandmother's home. Name not given.
Character mentioned in Mrs. Mosse, who is considered the area rake and shows interest in Fanny.
A person whom the title character of Mrs. Mosse remembers. Name not given.
Character mentioned in Mrs. Mosse. He offends Mitford's maternal grandfather by saluting his wife. Name not given.
Character mentioned in Mrs. Mosse. He, along with along with his children, is among the many visitors to Mitford's maternal grandmother's home. Name not given.
Charactor mentioned in Mrs. Mosse, whose daughter imprudently marries the son of Dr. Russell's first wife. Name not given.
Character mentioned in Mrs. Mosse, who imprudently marries the son of Dr. Russell's first wife. Name not given.

The first wife of Mitford's maternal grandfather. She is recalled in Mrs. Mosse as a wealthy widow with a son, considerably older than her husband, and someone who thought herself better than other people. Forename not given.

person.persName: Dr. Russell's first wife's former husband
person.note: The first husband of Mitford's maternal grandfather's first wife. He is mentioned in Mrs. Mosse. Name not given.

person.persName: son of the first Mrs. Russell
person.note: The son of the first wife of Mitford's maternal grandfather, who makes a bad marital match that shames his mother. He is recalled in Mrs. Mosse. Name not given.

person.persName: The second wife of Mitford's maternal grandfather. She is recalled in Mrs. Mosse, and is remembered chiefly for participating in an innoculation party. Forename not given.

person.note: In Shakespeare's The Tempest, he is King of the Fairies, married to Titania. In order to win a dispute with his wife over the fate of a child, Oberon causes his wife to fall in love with a human whose head has been turned into a donkey's.
A significant opponent of Mr. Sidney at whist in An Old Bachelor. Name not given.
Character of the gardener to Mr. Sidney who appears in An Old Bachelor. Name not given.

person.persName: girl at party in An Old Bachelor
person.note: A young girl mentioned in An Old Bachelor who attends Mr. Sidney's Christmas parties along with the narrator when she was a child. Name not given.
Character of the long-lived occupant of the unnamed rectorythat Mr. Sidney is waiting to occupy in An Old Bachelor. Name not given.

person.persName: young visitor in An Old Bachelor
person.note: Character who is visiting the Our Village narrator's family when the story of Mr. Sidney is told in An Old Bachelor. Name not given.

Obscure author of tracts on the poor laws and on the French Revolution who is discussed by the title character of the sketch, The Talking Lady. He is someone on whose life she can give minute details. Mentioned with irritation by the narrator.
The husband of Charlotte Page who appears in Ellen.
Character from Ellen. Charlotte is the twin sister of Ellen, daughter of the rector of N.. She is the livelier of the two sisters, and becomes engaged to a soon-to-be ordained man.
Title character of Ellen. She is the daughter of a rector, twin sister of Charlotte Page. She is the less lively and less preferred of the two sisters. She becomes engaged to Colonel Falkner.
Character mentioned in Ellen. She is the deceased mother of Charlotte Page and Ellen Page.
Character in Henry Fielding's novel, Joseph Andrews. He believes the best of everyone, and is often the victim of deceit.
Character mentioned in several Our Village sketches as the man who marries Phoebe. He is unnamed, and said to be a patten-maker.

persName.roleName: King of England and of France and Lord of Ireland

person.note: Prince Hal is typically known as the youthful character of King Henry V before he became king, as made famous in Shakespeare's plays Henry IV Part 1 and Henry IV Part 2. In these plays, he carouses with Falstaff and other colorful, low-born characters, rendering his interest in ruling the kingdom a matter of critical debate. In Shakespeare's Henry IV Part 1, it is Hal who kills Hotspur at the Battle of Shrewsbury.
A spaniel belonging to Joel Brent, mentioned in A Village Beau.

One of the country boys whom the narrator of Our Village encounters or mentions in a number of sketches, notably Frost and Thaw and A Country Cricket Match. In his Mitford papers, Francis Needham identifies two local boys by this name on whom this character may have been based.
Character of the rector from Ellen. He is the widowed father of Charlotte and Ellen Page. He has a good living in N. as well as an estate in Ireland. Forename not given.

Outlaw hero of medieval legend who, together with his merry men, figures in ballads, broadsides, plays, games, proverbs, film, and television from the fourteenth century till our own time, but whose historal existence remains a matter of debate. He is a complex figure in the long tradition that he occupies, but is best known as a benevolent outlaw, who battles the Sheriff of Nottingham for the good of the poor. In Mitford's time, the most influential scholars on Robin Hood were Thomas Percy and Joseph Ritson. Their antiquarian research helped shape a national English hero, and influenced Walter Scott's depiction of the character in Ivanhoe, as well as the representations found in John Keats' short poem, and Thomas Love Peacock's novel, Maid Marian.

Character mentioned in Mrs. Mosse. Mitford may be referring to the real-life sister of Mary Russell. In the sketch, Fanny gains the attentions of the neighborhood rake, Sir Thomas S.. Surname not given.
Character who appears in Mrs. Mosse. Although she is the unnamed in the sketch, she is identified as Mitford's maternal grandmother, the third wife of her grandfather.
Mary Russell Mitford's maternal grandfather, Richard Russell, as he is described but not named in Mrs. Mosse.
The dog who belonged to Mitford's maternal grandfather, and that is described vividly by the title character in Mrs. Mosse.
The village schoolmistress mentioned in Our Village. She is said frequently to let herself be dominated by Lizzy.
Character of the Three Mile Cross schoolmaster who is mentioned in The Hard Summer. Name not given.
Character who appears in Tom Cordery. We learn that one of Tom's legendary feats was to level him to the ground with a dead hare.
The main character of An Old Bachelor. Forename not given.

Character who appears in Bramley Maying who reveals that the narrator and her companion have reached Silchester. She gives the narrator and her companion directions to the Maying as they make their way to the festival. Name not given.
Character who appears in A Country Cricket Match. He is the third person chosen to join the Shinfield cricket team, known as a fast thrower. He is the brother of John Simmons.
Character who appears in A Country Cricket Match. He is a member of the Shinfield cricket team, known for his good fielding skills, and he is the brother of George Simmons.
A wealthy baronet from Waleswho appears in the Cousin Mary. He hires Mary as a governess for his children, but later marries her. Full name not given.

Princess character made famous by Charles Perrault in his Stories or Tales of Times Past, who falls asleep for one hundred years after a spindle prick, and awakens just at the moment that a prince approaches her. Perrault's version of the tale follows the princess and prince after their marriage, when the prince's ogre-mother attempts to kill the princess and her children.
Character in Henry Fielding's novel, Tom Jones. He is the good-natured guardian of the novel's title character.

Character who appears in A Country Cricket Match. He is the son of the village mason, although his occupation is not given. He is rejected from the Shinfield cricket team for being too tall and lacking in strength, but is later called on to play after James Brown abandons the team.
A soldier who appears in The Talking Gentleman. He becomes concerned about Harry L. when he witnesses him apparently talking to himself. Name not given.
Cousin of the title character of the sketch, . She is mentioned in passing. Surname not given.
A person who is the subject of the the talking lady's endless talk. Forename not given.
A person who is the subject of the the talking lady's endless chatter. Name not given.
A person who is the subject of the the talking lady's endless talk. Forename not given.
One of the passengers on the mail coach with whom the title character of The Talking Lady shares her journey west. Name not given.
One of the passengers on the mail coach with whom the title character of the sketch, The Talking Lady shares her journey west. Name not given.
One of the passengers on the mail coach with whom the title character of the sketch, The Talking Lady shares her journey west. Name not given.

The last nephew of the title character of the sketch, The Talking Lady whose death leads her to move in with the widow, and subsequently, to take the trip that brings her to visit the the narrator's family. Name not given.
A woman who is mentioned as having unsuccessfully set up house with the title character of The Talking Lady. Name not given.
Unnamed title character of the The Talking Lady. She is an old acquaintance of the narrator's father, possibly based on someone Mitford knew. In The Talking Gentleman, she is mentioned to have died.
This horse appears in The Visit. He belongs to the Our Village narrator's Farley Hill friend, and comically refuses to obey her directions.

In Shakespeare's The Tempest, she is Queen of the Fairies. As a result of a marital dispute over the fate of a child, she is tricked by her husband, Oberon, to fall in love with a human whose head has been transformed into that of a donkey.
Character mentioned in the sketch Tom Cordery. Surname not given.
Character who appears in Tom Cordery. He acts as something of an ally and friend to Tom by turning a blind eye to his poaching. Name not given.

Character mentioned in the sketch Tom Cordery. It is difficult to discern anything about this character other than that he is a member of the nobility. In the story, he appears as someone about whom Tom tells hunting tales to distract and tempt his clients into unattractive hunting grounds. Name not given.

person.persName: Overseer of estate forename not given surname not given
person.note: Character who appears in Tom Cordery. He is the overseer of the estate on which Tom's cottage sits. He declines to repair the Corderys' cottage after a snowfall destroys the roof.
A character in The Faerie Queene. She accompanies the Redcrosse Knight as he journeys to fight a monster, and later rescues him from captivity at the hands of a giant.
A young carpenter who competes with Joel Brent_for the affections of Harriet in A Village Beau. Name not given.
In Violeting, this character is mentioned as a landlord whose carelessness has affected his tenants and the farmhouse they live in. Name not given.
An old man whom the narrator sees digging in workhouse garden in Violeting. Name not given.
In Violeting, this character is mentioned as a tenant who lives in an old farmhouse that is crumbling due to the careless landlord. Name not given.
Mr. Sidney's pet terrier in An Old Bachelor.
The character of the coachman whom the narrator observes in The Hard Summer. Name not given.
An overheated character mentioned in The Hard Summer whom the narrator sees in the coach. Name not given.
A character who assists the narrator water her flowers during a drought in The Hard Summer. It is suggested they work in a stable. Name not given.
An overheated character mentioned in The Hard Summer whom the narrator sees in the coach. Name not given.
An overheated character mentioned in The Hard Summer whom the narrator sees in the coach. Name not given.
Character of an 8-year old cricket player who appears in The Hard Summer. The narrator does not know his name, and so she denotes him by his dress, which resembles that of a hussar.
An overheated character mentioned in The Hard Summer whom the narrator sees in the coach. Name not given.
Character mentioned in The Hard Summer as a prosperous, industrious local farmer. He is married to Mrs. Welles. Forename not given.
Character mentioned in The Hard Summer. She is the wife of Master Welles, and together, they run a prosperous farm in the area. Her forename is not given. Forename not given.
Sally Wheeler is one of the women vying for the affections of Joel Brent in the Our Village sketch, A Village Beau.
Character mentioned in The First Primrose. The son of a farmer, he is the cheery husband of Rachel White. They are noted to be a cheerful, industrious, poor family of fourteen children.
Character introduced in The First Primrose. She is described as a jovial woman, married to Joseph White, daughter of Mr. Hilton, a former gamekeeper. She and her husband have fourteen children.

Character who appears in A Country Cricket Match. He is the eleventh person chosen for the Shinfield cricket team, and the fifteen-year old brother of Robert Willis. Francis Needham's archival research found references to three blacksmiths from a Willis family, including David.

Character who appears in A Country Cricket Match. He is the tenth member chosen for the Shinfield cricket team. He is the brother of David Willis. Francis Needham's archival research found three local blacksmiths from a Willis family, including a John, Thomas, and David, but none named Robert.
A ghostly white lady, described in The First Primrose, who is said to haunt a small pool near the narrator's old house.
The landlord of the narrator and her family. He may be based on Richard Body. Name not given.
In Violeting, the narrator facetiously imagines how a long-ago lord was prevented by the sturdy farmers from making an enclosure in Shinfield parish. Name not given.
A character mentioned in The Visit. He is said to dislike Ben Kirby. Name not given.
This character is mentioned in The Visit when the narrator admires his house. Name not given.
This character is mentioned in The Visit. He is said to have pulled down his picturesque house and mill and put up modern buildings. Name not given.

org.note: In Greek mythology, the Myrmidons were people of Phthia who were destroyed by a plague and later re-created from ants. In The Iliad, they are the soldiers who are loyal to Achilles

place.note: The capital city of Antwerp Province in the Flemish Region, known colloquially as Flanders, in Belgium. Before the Reformation, Antwerp rose to become a powerful trading city under the rule of the Spanish. With the Union of Utrecht in 1579, the city became part of the United Provinces of the Netherlands, and the port was subsequently closed by treaty agreement, leading to the decline in the city's trading status. During Mitford's lifetime, Antwerp was controlled by Napoleonic France, and after the Battle of Waterloo, it became part of the Kingdom of the United Netherlands until 1832, when it was joined to Belgium following a siege by French forces.

A mountainous, landlocked, independent republic in the center of Europe. During Mitford's time, Austria was part of the Empire of Austria, which had been proclaimed in 1804, shortly before the dissolution of the Holy Roman Empire in 1806. The Empire of Austria was a multinational power that unified the territorial possessions of the Habsburg monarchs into an administrative unit. After the defeat of Napoleon, the Austrian Empire was incorporated into the German Confederation, an alliance between German-speaking member states, where it became essential to the functioning of that entity. The German Confederation was dissolved in 1867, and the Austrian Empire became part of Austria-Hungary.
Area within the London City Corporation.

Beaurepaire House was the seat and estate of the Brocas family, located near Bramley, and including substantial lands. The house was demolished and replaced with a gothic-style manor around 1738, and was home to Bernard Brocas until his death, though it remained in the family and sometimes visited Harriot Brocas. The estate remained in the family until it was sold in 1870.
A fashionable shopping street in London.
Village in Hampshire, located ten miles south of Reading, near Silchester.
English country house that has been the seat of the Earls of Essex since Elizabethan times. Its name is featured in stories and poems about Henry Cecil and his second wife, Sarah Hoggins.

An area that was set aside for the poor at the enclosure of Mortimer Common in 1802. The spot is a possible location in Tom Cordery for the place where the protagonist leads his clients on unsuccessful hunting trips.
A northern suburb of Reading, located on the Thames river, near the Chiltern Hills. In Mitford's time, Caversham was within Oxfordshire.
An escarpment of chalky lands located northwest of London. The system comprises 665 square miles.

City in the West Midlands in England. Before the industrial revolution, Coventry was the most important city in the Midlands, though it remained famous for clock- and watch-making. It is also the basis for the phrase, which Mitford uses in several contexts, send to Coventry, which means to ignore or eject someone from society.
The county of Devonshire, now known as Devon, in the south west of England.
A county in South West England on the English Channel coast. While known as Dorset today, it was archaically known as Dorsetshire.

A steep set of ridged hills that offer views of three counties. The land was once owned by London Times editor, John Walter, and a MRM acquaintance. It is now a National Trust property that includes Simons Wood. It is possibly the site of the Ridges where the party goes walking in Cousin Mary.

Capital city of the Tuscany region of Italy. Florence is generally cited as the birthplace of the European Renaissance. This is due to writers like Petrarch and Dante, who worked the city. From the early modern period to the early eighteenth century, the city was ruled by the powerful Medici family. They helped usher in a period of intense artistic and literary creation through their patronage of artists like Michelangelo, Leonardo da Vinci, and Botticelli. During Mitford's time, Florence was incorporated into the domains of Austria in 1737, then was annexed to France during the Napoleonic Wars. It was later restored as part of the Austrian Empire until its royal family, the Habsburg-Lorraines was deposed in 1859.

A piece of ground near Mortimer Common where a murderer was hanged and that retained the chains that the condemned man wore. Mitford recalls going to this place in a letter of January 13, 1842 to Elizabeth Barrett Browning. It may be the spot mentioned in Tom Cordery where two murderers were hanged.

Country bordering the Aegean, Ionian, and Mediterranean Seas, and comprising a mainland area and thousands of islands. It is sometimes referred to as the birthplace of Western civilization for the enduring influence its political structures, ancient philosophers, and poets exerted on later generations, including Roman poets. The country as it is today was united under Philip of Macedon, and later extended by his son, Alexander the Great to encompass areas as far as India. In 1460, most of Greece became part of the Ottoman Empire, except for a few Ionian islands that were part of the Venetian republic. During Mitford's time, Greeks under Ottoman rule began a war for independence, which concluded in 1832 when three European powers, England, France, and Russia, installed the Barvarian Otto von Wittelsbach to rule the country as a monarch. He was deposed in 1862 in a revolution.
City located on the Thames, about nine miles from Reading.
A channel that runs through Reading off the Kennet River.
Tributary of the Thames running through Berkshire and Wiltshire.
Tributary of the Thames that flows 28 miles northward from Basingstoke through Swallowfield, Shinfield to Wargrave. The river has for centuries been a location for milling operations.
Forest in north Hampshire, near Silchester. Possibly referenced as the forest of P in Lucy.

Pleasure garden that was located in Chelsea, which during Mitford's time was a suburb of London. The gardens were opened to the public in 1742, and immediately came to rival Vauxhall for the fashionable people it attracted. Its grounds featured a rotunda where notable musical performances were held. It is now part of the grounds of Chelsea Hospital.
The 481-mile long river that flows from northeastern France through Paris, Le Havre/Honfleur, and into the English Channel.
