Village in East Hampshire on the northern most boundary of what is currently South Downs National Park. Gilbert White made his natural observations here when writing A Naturalist's Calendar and The Natural History and Antiquities of Selborne.
Artificial lake, created in 1730 that occupies 40 acres in Hyde Park.

Shinfield parish is located in the county of Berkshire and contains Three Mile Cross, Spencer's Wood, Grazeley, and the village of Shinfield. During Mitford's time, Many of Mitford's sketches are set in and around the parish.
Village in Hampshire, nine miles from Reading, known for its Roman ruins. It is featured in several stories in Our Village, sometimes by name, sometimes through the abbreviation S.
Part of the Roman ruins in the town of Silchester.

place.placeName: Spice Islands Maluku Islands the Moluccas
place.note: An archipelago in the east of Indonesia that, from the seventeenth to the nineteenth centuries, was a center for the culture of cloves, mace, and nutmeg for colonizing European powers such as the Netherlands and Portugal. During Mitford's time, the region was under British control.

Church located in Bramley, that dates from the tweflth century, undergoing many renovations since that time. The church is notable for its beautiful stained glass and its elaborate marble tomb sculpture of Bernard Brocas. It is featured in Bramley Maying, where the narrator and her companion take a tour.
A district in the City of Westminster, London. The area was being developed in Mitford's time as a suburban residential location.

Estate acquired through marriage by the second earl of Clarendon. The estate sits where the rivers Loddon and Blackwater join. The estate had been the property of the Backhouse family, who occupied an old Tudor mansion that was renovated and modernized. Swallowfield Park was subsequently sold by Hyde's son, the third earl, to Thomas 'Diamond' Pitt, great-grandfather of William Pitt the younger. He had made his fortune in India, famously by the sale of a large diamond to the Regent of France. The Swallowfield estate remained in the Pitt family until 1737 when it was sold to John Dodd. In 1783, Dodd's descendents sold it to Sylvanus Bevan, whose descendents sold it in turn in 1788 to Timothy Hare Earle, Esq. By Mitford's time, the estate had passed to Earle's son, Timothy Hare Altabon Earle. As a result of financial losses the latter had suffered in the West Indies on account of the abolition of British participation in the slave trade, he sold Swallowfield in 1820 to Sir Henry Russell. Sir Henry had recently returned to England, having spent 1798 to 1814 in India. By 1825, Sir Henry began making renovations to the property, together with son, Henry, who himself inherited Swallowfield in 1836. Mitford developed a close friendship with Lady Marie Clotilde Russell, his wife.
Swallowfield and Its Owners by Lady Constance Russell
Swallowfield Park, Berkshire by Margot Finn
A seventeenth-century public house and coaching inn next to which the Mitford family lived in Three Mile Cross. It is featured in Our Village as the Rose Inn.

Department in western France, traditionally believed to be the birthplace of Elinor of Acquitaine. During the French Revolution, the Vendee mounted a fierce resistance to the revolutionary government and later refused to recognize Napoleon's legitimacy after his escape from Elba.

The city, consisting of 118 islands in the Venetian lagoon and located in the northeastern region of Italy, has a long history stretching back into antiquity. From 697, Venice was a Republic, a city state with its own autonomous elected government of aristocrats and oligarchs, ruled by a Doge. At its height, the Republic of Venice included the Veneto region of what is now Italy, the Fruili-Venezia Giulia region that encompasses parts of present-day Austria and Slovenia, and the Istria Peninsula. The end of the Venetian Republic came in 1797 when Napoleon invaded, and ceded the territory to Austria, forcing the Doge to abdicate. In 1866, following the defeat of the Austrians, Venice was handed over to a unified Italy.
Location of Mr. and Mrs. Newell's farm in St. Giles parish, Berkshire, and possibly the model for the great farmhouse at M. in A Great Farmhouse.
A landlocked county that borders Berkshire, Gloucesteshire, Oxfordshire, Hampshire, Somerset, and Dorset. It encompasses Old Sarum, Salisbury, Salisbury Plain, and the Stonehenge site.
Estate purchased by the Bernard Brocas shortly before his death in 1777, and extensively renovated by his wife, Harriet. In Bramley Maying, Mitford mentions W. Park, which refers to Wokefield.
Place of employment of Joseph Hearne from A Country Cricket Match. The mills are located in an adjacent parish.
In Greek mytholody, Arcadia was the home to the god Pan, and in classical literature, indicated an unspoilt wilderness of innocence and pleasure.
A location mentioned in The Visit, located in F. Hill, near the home of the narrator's friend from F. Hill whom she visits in that sketch. Original site as yet unidentified.
The city of B. is Mitford's screened reference to Reading in Our Village. She indicates this in a letter to Sir William Elford of June 23, 1824.

In the Bible, Babel is a city and tower built in the land of Shinar that was intended to reach up to heaven. In retalitation, Yahweh causes the people to speak different languages so they no longer understand one another.
Site of the Maying that the narrator of Our Village attends in Bramley Maying.
Park mentioned in Frost and Thaw as being flooded.

A town or village mentioned in Modern Antiques. It is said to be in the vicinity of the garden that belongs to Mrs. Frances and Mrs. Theodosia. Since it is mentioned as being located near the Thames and within view of chalky hills, Mitford could be referring to Caversham. A similarly abbreviated town name occurs in Frost and Thaw, but it is not clear whether Mitford is referring to the same town.
Town mentioned in Frost and Thaw as being flooded. It is not clear whether it is the same town designated with the same initial in Modern Antiques.
The manufacturing town that, in Cousin Mary, the title character moves to for some months before taking a position as a governess. It is described as smokey. Location unidentified.
The loosely-screened name that Mitford gives to Farley Hill in Our Village. It is described elaborately as a new development in The Visit.
The house belonging to William Falkner and Miss Falkner. Mentioned in Ellen.
The common named in A Country Cricket Match used by the opposing teams for their cricket match. It is located within Shinfield parish.
The home of Miss Falkner and Colonel Falkner in Ellen. .
A desolate common, set aside after enclosure, where Tom Cordery enjoys bringing the narrator and his unwary gentleman clients in Tom Cordery. The area may be based on Mortimer Common's Burnt Common.

The chief setting of Tom Cordery. Mitford may be indicating the village of Mortimer Common, or more specifically the common lands around it that are said to be partially enclosed at the time the story takes place.
Abbreviation used for the area in which the great farmhouse is located, from the sketch of the Our Village sketch of the same name.
The farm whose inhabitants the narrator recalls in A Great Farmhouse.
Town mentioned in A Country Cricket Match said to be located twelve miles from Shinfield parish. It is the residence of Mary Allen. Location as yet unidentified.
Small village that the narrator tours in Bramley Maying. Mitford is probably referring to Mortimer Common village.
A small town in Dorsetshire where Charlotte Page, Ellen Page, and their father reside in Ellen.
The unnamed rectory that Mr. Sidney waits most of his adult life to occupy in An Old Bachelor.
The unnamed College where Mr. Sidneyis a fellow while awaiting a vacancy at the unnamed rectory in An Old Bachelor.
Oak forest mentioned as being located near Lucy's new home after she marries and moves to the city of S--.. Possibly the forest of Pamber.
Property belonging to Rector Page that is located in Ireland. Mentioned in the Our Village sketch Ellen.
The house belonging to Rector Page in the town of N., featured in the Our Village sketch Ellen.
An elevated ridge where the Our Village narrator and her friends climb in donkey carts and by foot in Cousin Mary. It may be the Finchampstead Ridges.
The Rose Inn is mentioned many times as the local inn in Our Village. It is based on the real-life Swan Inn, next to which the Mitfords lived in Three Mile Cross.
City or town on the stagecoach route from B. in Our Village. It is not clear whether this is the same location as the city of S. mentioned in Bramley Maying and Lucy.
Town described in Lucy as a beautiful, Roman-walled town, and mentioned as the eventual residence of Lucy after her marriage. Probably Silchester.
Parish mentioned in A Country Cricket Match as the home of a rival cricket team. It is located to the southeast of the village parish. Location as yet unidentified.
The town mentioned as the usual residence of the title character of the sketch, The Talking Lady.
A crumbling old farmhouse that the narrator mourns in the sketch, Violeting.
Estate mentioned in the Our Village story, Bramley Maying. Probably refers to Wokefield Park.
A steep, corkscrew-like hill described in A Great Farmhouse on which the farmer's greyhound, Helen proudly kills an old hare.
Town mentioned in Frost and Thaw. Not yet identified.
The parish workhouse mentioned in several Our Village sketches.

item.name: Fly
item.note: In the The First Primrose, Fly is the dog owned by farmer Barnard.

item.name: Hector
item.note: An exquisite greyhound belonging to the farmer in A Great Farmhouse.

item.name: Helen
item.note: A greyhound featured in A Great Farmhouse.

list.item: fawn Chordata Artiodactyla Cervidae A fawn is a young deer, under one year old.-->

item.name: golden beetle
golden tortoise beetle
Charidotella
C. sexpunctata
Chrysomelidae
item.note: A species of leaf beetle that is native to the Americas.

item.name: currants
ribes
Grossulariaceae, or a separate genus of Grossularia
item.note: Mitford calls this plant a currant-bush, which is actually another name for the conkerberry or bush plum, but these grow best in tropical regions and are likely not what she means.

item.name: damask rose
item.note: A rose hybrid that is renowned for its fine fragrance.

item.name: elm
Ulmus
Ulmaceae
item.note: The elm is highly prominent in literature, with its first presence in the Iliad. It is also in the Aeneid, as the Stygian Elm. Virgil refers to a Roman superstition that elms were trees of ill-omen because their fruit seemed to have no value. Two elm-motifs have risen from classical literature: the Paradisal elm motif, representing pastoral idylls, and the Elm and Death motif. Many references to elm from the Renaissance onwards fit one of these two categories. The elm also holds political significance. The cutting of the elm was a diplomatic altercation between the Kings of France and England in 1188. In England, after the Glorious Revolution of 1688, the 'Dutch Elm' hybrid was planted and become popular with enthusiasts o the new political order. Furthermore, the 'Liberty Tree' was an American white elm in Boston. In 1775, the British felled it, and the Americans planted 'Liberty Elms' and sewed elm symbols on to their reolutionary flags.

item.name: grape
Vitis
Vitaceae
item.note: A grape is a fruit, botanically a berry, of the deciduous woody vines of the flowering plant genus Vitis.

item.name: nose-gay
item.note: Also called tussie-mussie or a posey, the nose-gay is composed of a mixture of flowers and herbs, edged with paper frill or greens. They are associated with the floral language of love, and were popular in Victorian England. Different arrangements signified different relationship statuses.

item.name: potato
Solanum
S. tuberosum
Solanaceae
item.note: Potatoes were relatively new to Europe during Mitford's time. They are native to the Andes and were introduced only in the second half of the sixteenth century by the Spanish.

item.name: rose-tree
rosa
rosaceae
item.note: There are over a hundred species of roses, but not all of them are suitable to be made into what is known as a rose-tree.

event.label: Act for the Abolition of the Slave Trade
event.note: The Parliamentary Act passed in 1807 that abolished English participation in the slave trade. England continued to hold and operate slave plantations in its colonies for several decades afterwards.

event.label: Slavery Abolition Act

An Act for the Abolition of Slavery throughout the British Colonies; for promoting the Industry of the manumitted Slaves; and for compensating the Persons hitherto entitled to the Services of such Slaves
event.note: British law that provided for the gradual abolition of slavery throughout most of the colonies. Several areas, notably those in possession of the British East India Company, were excluded by this Act. The Act also provided for payments to be made to slave holders.

event.label: An Act for the Union of Great Britain and Ireland
Union with Ireland Act 1800
Act of Union (Ireland) 1800
event.note: Two Acts that were passed simultaneously by the British Parliament and the Parliament of Ireland which effectively merged the two countries, creating the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland.

event.label: Peninsular War
the War of Spanish Independence
event.note: Part of the Napoleonic Wars, the Peninsular War was fought between the French against an alliance of Spanish, Portuguese, and British armies. Napoleon occupied Portugal and parts of Spain, forcing the abdication of King Charles IV and his son, King Ferdinand VI. They were replaced with Napoleon's own brother, Joseph Bonaparte. The war was fought through guerilla tactics and direct military engagements, and enhanced the career of the Duke of Wellington, who fought across the Pyrenees to push back Bonaparte's forces. At the conclusion of the war, King Ferdinand reascended the throne.

item.note: White marble tomb sculpted by Thomas Banks, dedicated to Bernard Brocas. The tomb's effigy represents a dying Brocas in the arms of his wife. It was installed in the church of St. James in Bramley around 1800. Mitford saw the monument on May 23, 1822, and the piece is described in Bramley Maying.

figure.note: Portrait of a young woman wearing a black straw hat.

bibl.title: The Four Times of the Day
bibl.author: William Hogarth

figure.note: A four-part series of paintings by Hogarth set in different parts of London, at distinct times of the day, and titled accordingly: Morning, Noon, Evening, and Night. Each work features figures from various classes of people going about their business. The series was engraved and published in 1738.

bibl.title: The Maid of the Mill
The First Scene of the Maid of the Mill
A Catalogue Raisonne of the Engraved Works of William Woollett
bibl.author: William Woollett

figure.note: Engraving modeled after stage scene painting by John Inigo Richards. It depicts a young man gesturing while walking across a mill yard surrounded by three buildings, being watched on the right by a young woman from a second-floor house window, and two other women on the left who are mending a net outside a barn. Two older men work in the mill in the background.

bibl.title: Animal Biography, or Authentic Anecdotes of the Lives, Manners, and Economy of the Animal Creation
bibl.author: William Bingley
bibl.note: A popular work of natural history that eventually expanded into four volumes and went into six editions. Covering animals and insects from all over the world, the book makes use of the work of predecessors, such as Linnaeus and Gilbert White to present minute descriptions of animal life.

bibl.title: The Book of Common Prayer and Administration of the Sacraments and other Rites and Ceremonies of the Church, according to the use of the Church of England, Together with the Psalter or Psalms of David, pointed as they are to be Sung or said in churches
bibl.author: Thomas Cranmer
bibl.note: The established liturgy of the Church of England. The book was first composed during the English Reformation, and aimed to make the rituals of the church more accessible to the worshippers by describing them in English rather than Latin. It encompasses forms of worship, service, prayers, and sacraments. Its use was authorized by Parliament in 1549, and it has undergone important revisions over the centuries. Many phrases from the book have gone into common discourse.

bibl.title: The Castle of Indolence. An allegorical poem. Written in imitation of Spenser
bibl.author: James Thomson
bibl.note: Thomson's final poem, published just before he died. The two-canto work, which is written in Spenserian stanzas, satirically pits a languid world ruled over by an archimage named Indolence against a space where the Knights of Arts and Industry bring activity and progress to England. The poem was widely excerpted and quoted by later poets and novelists.

bibl.title: The Ballad of Chevy Chase
bibl.author: anonymous
bibl.note: An old English ballad that tells the story of the dispute between Percy, the Duke of Northumberland and the Scottish Earl Douglas over hunting. It was much admired in Mitford's time, having been published in a number of ballad collections, including Reliques of Ancient English Poetry. Its tune had also been adapted with other lyrics.

bibl.title: An Epistle to Benjamin Bridgewater, occasion'd by the death of the late Queen Mary
bibl.author: John Tutchin
bibl.note: An elegy on the death of Queen Mary II, urging the bereaved king to get back to the business of defending the nation against enemies.

bibl.title: Joe Miller's Jests
or the Wits Vade-Mecum
bibl.author: John Mottley
bibl.note: A book of jokes that was published one year after the death of its titular author, Joe Miller. First published as a pamphlet, this publication was so successful that it went into three editions. Later joke books bearing his name followed, under slightly different titles. Joe Miller books remained well known until the nineteenth century.

bibl.title: The Diverting History of John Gilpin Shewing how he went Farther than he intended, and came safe Home again
bibl.author: William Cowper
bibl.note: Comic ballad about a man who steals a runaway horse. It was initially published in The Public Advertiser, but later collected with The Task.

bibl.title: The History of the Adventures of Joseph Andrews and of his friend Mr. Abraham Adams
bibl.author: Henry Fielding
bibl.note: This picaresque novel, a loose satirical response to Pamela, tells of Pamela's brother's adventures on his way to London with his companion Parson Adams. Joseph Andrews is dismissed from service for rejecting the advances of Lady Booby, the wife of his deceased employer, and meets Parson Adams who is on the way to sell his sermons in London.

bibl.title: A Journal of the Plague Year
History of the Plague in London
bibl.author: Daniel Defoe
H.F.
bibl.note: Often described as a historical novel, Defoe's work is presented as the eyewitness account of a London saddler to the events of the bubonic plague outbreak in London in the year 1665. Defoe was about five years old when the plague broke out, so it is unlikely that the narrative of events and places are from his own perspective or are meant to be taken as a genuine eyewitness account, despite the verisimilitude of the text. Defoe may have consulted the journals of his uncle, Henry Foe, the H.F. of the pseudonym, for some of his material.

bibl.title: The Last Letters of Jacopo Ortis
bibl.author: Ugo Foscolo
bibl.note: Epistolary novel in the spirit of Goethe's The Sorrows of Young Werther but with political overtones that link the hero, Ortis, to the Venetian struggle for indepependence and liberty. The protagonist is in love with a woman, Teresa, who is betrothed to another, while also enduring dashed political hopes with fall of Venice into the hands of Austria. He communicates his feelings to a friend in letters while on his travels. Mitford records in her journal reading this book on June 15, 1820.

bibl.title: Le Sylph
Le Sylph

title.foreign: ou le mari comme il y en a peu

bibl.author: Martin de Choisy
bibl.note: A comic French play in verse.

bibl.title: A Legend of Montrose
Tales of My Landlord
bibl.note: Novel published in the Third Series of the Tales of My Landlord, along with The Bride of Lammermoor. It tells the story of the conflict between the royalist Earl of Montrose and the Scottish Covenanters during the English Civil War, focusing as well on the personal struggles between Allan M'Aulay and his romantic rival, the earl of Menteith for the affection of Annot Lyle.

bibl.title: Lewis's Miscellany
bibl.note: More research needed on this publication.

bibl.title: Life of Samuel Johnson, L.L.D.
bibl.author: James Boswell
bibl.note: Influential and controversial biography of Samuel Johnson that came to set a standard for life-writing in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries.

bibl.title: The Lover's Melancholy
bibl.author: John Ford
bibl.note: This play by John Ford was based on Robert Burton's Anatomy of Melancholy. It was first performed in 1628 at the Blackfriar's and the Globe Theaters. By Mitford's time, the play had garnered the praise of Charles Lamb, who anthologized portions in his Specimens of English Dramatic Poets.

bibl.title: Love's Labour's Lost
A Pleasant and Conceited Comedie Called Loves Labours Lost [sic]
bibl.author: William Shakespeare
bibl.note: Shakespeare's comedy of disguises and love tests features Ferdinand, the King of Navarre and three friends, Berowne, Longaville, and Dumaine, who renounce love in favor of study, only to be thrown into passion by an embassy visit from the Princess of France and her three friends. The men decide to give up their oath to renounce love, and to woo the women but in disguise as Russians. The women, as a jest, swap their own identities in order to hear the suits and mock the men, but in the end, the Princess must return to France when her father dies. She gives King Ferdinand and his friends a command to spend the year performing certain tasks in order to gain the consent of the women to marriage. The play was published in the First Folio.

bibl.title: The Maid of La Vendee, being a second edition of Clara de Montfier
Clara de Monfier; a moral tale
bibl.author: Elizabeth Anne LeNoir
bibl.note: The Maid of La Vendee is the re-titled second edition of Elizabeth LeNoir's 1808 novel, Clara de Montfier. Both editions appear to have been published by members of LeNoir's family, who owned and operated the Reading Mercury.
Biography of Elizabeth LeNoir by Laura Ridley. Corvey 'Adopt an Author'

bibl.title: A Naturalist's Calendar: with Observations in Various Branches of Natural History
bibl.author: Gilbert White
bibl.note: This book, published posthumously, gives precise accounts of the actions of animals, bird sounds, and weather phenomena, all of which were noted by hand in tabular form by the author, and rendered in the same format in the book. It was later often republished with The Natural History and Antiquities of Selborne.

bibl.title: The Natural History and Antiquities of Selborne
bibl.author: Gilbert White
bibl.note: This influential book of nature writing is ostensibly formed from 110 letters addressed by the author to Thomas Pennant, a zoologist, and Daines Barrington, a fellow of the Royal Society. In each letter, some of which were composed for the book itself, White describes his observations of local natural surroundings, flora, fauna, and geologic formation in minute detail. These observations were carefully prepared from notes White took over time, and were meant to be a scientific record of the natural phenomena under discussion, coupled with an assessment of the social conditions of the area. The book was immensely successful, and is considered an early example of ecological exploration. It was a favorite book of Mitford's, and she invokes it as a formal model for Our Village in the introductory sketch, and refers to it frequently.

bibl.title: Ode: Intimations of Immortality from Recollections of Early Childhood
bibl.author: William Wordsworth
bibl.note: Originally published in Poems, in Two Volumes, Wordsworth's eleven-stanza irregular Pindaric ode explores questions of the soul, and the wisdom of childhood.

bibl.title: On the Pleasure Arising from Vicissitude
Ode on the Pleasure Arising from Vicissitude
The Poems of Mr. Gray
bibl.author: Thomas Gray
bibl.note: An unfinished ode published posthumously.

bibl.title: The Palace of Truth: a moral tale
bibl.author: Madame de Genlis
bibl.note: A short story or novella written for the moral instruction of children. An English translation was produced in London in 1817.

bibl.title: Pamela; or, Virtue Rewarded
bibl.author: Samuel Richardson
bibl.note: This acclaimed, influential, but controversial epistolary novel tells the story of fifteen-year old Pamela Andrews, the daughter of laboring-class parents, as she fends off the sexual advances of her rakish employer, Mr. B. When he eventually proposes to her, she doubts his sincerity, but later realizes that she loves him, and accepts his proposal. The novel interrogates issues of class and gender as they affect feeling.

bibl.title: The Parish Register
Poems
bibl.author: George Crabbe
bibl.note: A pastoral poem by George Crabbe, recounting stories of the parish poor from the point of view of the clergyman. It is divided into three parts: Baptisms, Marriages, and Burials. The poem was published as part of a collection entitled Poems.

bibl.title: Pilgrim's Progress from This World, to that Which is to Come
bibl.author: John Bunyan
bibl.note: Allegorical novel that tells the story of a protagonist named Christian on a journey from the City of Destruction to the Celestial City. On his way, he meets various characters like Evangelist, Pliable, Mr. Legality and his son, Civility, as he roams through the Shadow of Death, the Slough of Despond, the Hill of Difficulty, and Wicket Gate. The first part of the book was written while Bunyan was in imprisoned in the county jail. He published the second part, which deals with Christian's wife and sons, several years later.

bibl.title: Poems in Two Volumes
bibl.author: William Wordsworth
bibl.note: Important collection of poems that succeeded Lyrical Ballads.

bibl.title: The Polite Letter Writer; containing a variety of plain, easy, entertaining, and familiar original letters, on Friendship, Business, Love, and Education.
bibl.note: A book detailing the rules of composition and providing examples of different types of letters. More research needed.

bibl.title: The Porter and the Three Ladies
bibl.note: A story from the first volume of Arabian Nights about three dervishes, along with a porter, the Caliph and his vizier, who spend an interesting evening at the home of three ladies of Baghdad.

bibl.title: Rule, Britannia!
bibl.author: Jame Thomson
Thomas Arne
bibl.note: Patriotic song generally associated with the British Navy. The lyrics were originally composed by Thomson, with music by Thomas Arne, for the masque Alfred, which was performed on August 2, 1740 at the home of Frederick, Prince of Wales. It was featured as the final song.

bibl.title: She Never Told Her Love
bibl.author: Joseph Haydn
bibl.note: A canzonette inspired by Twelfth Night.

bibl.title: The Silent Woman
Epicine
bibl.author: Ben Jonson
bibl.note: Comic play that premiered at the Whitefriars Theater in either December 1609 or January 1610. It was also the first play performed at the Restoration after the reopening of the theaters in 1660. The play features a noise-despising man named Morose who tries to disherit his nephew, Dauphine, by marrying. The nephew subsequently tricks Morose into marrying a mysteriously quiet woman, who turns out to be not only talkative, but also a boy.

bibl.author: William Shakespeare
bibl.note: Part of a song sequence performed as part of the play-within-the-play at the end of Love's Labour's Lost. This section is sung by Ver, the Spring, represented by the cuckoo.

bibl.title: Specimens of English Dramatic Poets, who lived about the time of Shakespeare
bibl.author: Charles Lamb
bibl.note: This anthology of excerpts from Elizabethan dramatists and poets helped popularize the era's authors for an early nineteenth century audience. The book included works by John Ford, Thomas Kyd, Thomas Decker, John Fletcher, Christopher Marlowe, and Ben Jonson, among others, with notes written by Lamb.

bibl.title:
Stories or Tales of Times Past Tales of Mother Goose
Histoire ou contes du temps passe
les contes de ma mere l'oye
bibl.author: Charles Perrault
bibl.note: Influential book of fairy tales that helped popularize such stories as Cinderella; or the Little Glass Slipper, Little Red Riding Hood, The Sleeping Beauty in the Wood, The Master Cat; or Puss in Bootsand Blue Beard. Perrault likely based his tales on those found in earlier European collections and those of some of his contemporaries, and incorporated the style and values of French aristocratic society, ending each tale with a moral. The first English translation of the book was published in 1729, leading to the stories' widespread popularity in various forms and versions, including as lavishly illustrated children's books well into the nineteenth century.

bibl.title: The Chronicle
The Chronicle
A Ballad
bibl.author: Abraham Cowley
bibl.note: A comic poem in which the author lists the names of many supposed mistresses and how the relationships ended.

bibl.title: The Minor
bibl.note: A comic play that ridiculed the Methodist preacher, George Whitefield. It was performed at The Haymarket in 1760, and subsequently moved to Drury Lane later that year.

bibl.title: The Seasons
bibl.author: James Thomson
bibl.note: A four-part, blank-verse pastoral poem sequence reflecting on the beauties of nature and God's plan. Thomson composed and published the poem in stages. He began with Winter in 1726, then Summer in 1727, Spring in 1729, and concluding with Autumn in 1730. All four parts were later published together under its full title in 1730. The work was influential on writers from the mid-eighteenth century to the nineteenth century for its contemplative feeling mixed with descriptions of scenery. Thomson continued to revise the poem and published a new version in 1746. The poem was very successful, inspiring most notably Joseph Haydn's oratorio of the same title.

bibl.title: The Picture; or The Lover's Resolution
Morning Post
bibl.author: Samuel Taylor Coleridge
bibl.title: Sybilline Leaves
bibl.note: Meditative poem first published in the Morning Post, and later published in the Love Poems section of Sybilline Leaves.

bibl.title: The Task: a Poem, in Six Books
bibl.author: William Cowper
bibl.note: An immensely influential long blank-verse poem that meditates on the blessings of nature and the retired life. The poem comments on war, slavery, despotism, and other issues of moment. Like other romantic-era writers, Mitford greatly admired the work.

bibl.author: George Farquhar
bibl.note: Comic play that was widely performed throughout the eighteenth century. It features the character of a recruiting sergeant named Kite, who attempts to trick a woman into marrying the Captain for whom he works.

bibl.title: Verses Making Part of an Epitaph on the Same Lady
A Collection of Poems in Six Volumes. By Several Hands.
bibl.author: George Lyttelton
bibl.note: A twelve-line elegy to George Lyttelton's first wife, which also became the inscription on her tombstone. It was much-quoted (and misquoted) into the nineteenth century, often with the gender changed to male and outside the context of elegy.

bibl.title: Yew Trees
Poems in Two Volumes
bibl.author: William Wordsworth
bibl.publisher: Longman, Hurst, Reese, Orme and Brown
bibl.note: Poem written around 1804 and published in the Poems of the Imagination section of the first volume of Poems in Two Volumes. It describes ancient trees, and imagines their longstanding relationship to history. Mitford admired the poem, and mentioned it to Sir William Elford in a letter from September 26, 1819.

bibl.title: English Local Government: The Story of the King's Highway
bibl.author: Sidney Webb
Beatrice Webb

bibl.title: Our Miss Austen: Jane Austen and Mary Russell Mitford--A New Appraisal
Persuasions: The Jane Austen Journal
bibl.author: Azar Hussain
